content: t have very much give to them and can cause constriction around the leg working toe-up allows for a stretchier cuff which is more forgiving to bigger legs  the toe portion of the pattern alternates increase rounds with rounds that maintain the stitch count this builds a deeper toe if you are making socks for a person with shorter toes you can skip the non-increase row for a custom fit that won t bunch up uncomfortably in their shoes make sure to get the measurement of their longest toe so you know how deep the sock toe must be made  these socks are made with a fully-fashioned heel gusset with a sole flap and a heel flap there is no need for you to cut your yarn until you have finished the leg cuff think of the heel as building an aztec pyramid with the stair-steps along the edge the sole flap resembles one of these pyramids very closely when you make the heel turn you ll be working the heel flap in the reverse of how you made the sole flap you ll join the flap edges together at the end of each row by working stitches into the sides of the flaps you ll be amazed at how the construction works without cutting the yarn  to make sure you have enough yarn to make the second sock match the first weigh your yarn before you start the pattern so you have an accurate weight measurement then as you get close to finishing the first sock weigh it again be sure to finish the first sock before you ve hit 50% of your total skein weight a kitchen scale works perfectly to measure yarn  experienced crocheters need not join rounds each row if you prefer the aesthetic of a seamless sock just be certain to mark the first stitch of each row so you know when you ve finished the round as this is key for starting your heel stitch guide written in us crochet terminology
